utterance: LS: Dual zooming during our break yesterday, and we had a seminar speaker from Johnson Matthew. They're talking about even for hydrogen. But as a mechanism for hydrogen storage, there is a significant push actually to convert electrochemically produced hydrogen, thermally convert it to ammonia for more easy transportation, and then thermal catalytically convert it back to hydrogen for the use. Now, there can be arguments can be made about whether that's useful or whether you would just want to use the ammonia once you've had it. But I'm kind of then looking at the economics of that sort of a process. Is it worth also an electro investigating an electrochemical route to ammonia production if this thermal route is is really so efficient that you can go back and forth simply as a means for more facile transportation even at scale.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: LS describes a seminar and current research on hydrogen storage and ammonia production as evidence for the economic considerations of different processes.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: LS explains the process of converting hydrogen to ammonia and back for transportation and use.
annotations.ask clarifying question: LS questions the economic viability of electrochemical ammonia production given the efficiency of thermal conversion processes for hydrogen storage and transportation.

utterance: AT: I would also add the argument of the localized production of ammonia. Those numbers that you just cited benefit hugely from the economy of scale and being able to have these energy recovery for the thermal recovery especially. So if you want to have a distributed network where nitrogen is obviously a distributed resource. Can you capitalize on that with such efficiencies?

annotations.expand on existing idea: AT adds to DK's point about hydrogen storage and transportation by bringing up the localized production of ammonia and its economic implications.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: AT supports their argument by mentioning the economy of scale and energy recovery benefits of thermal recovery cited by DK.
annotations.ask clarifying question: AT questions whether the efficiencies of centralized ammonia production can be replicated in a distributed network, given nitrogen's distributed nature.

utterance: HW: I can add something here for of course for the energy input from renewable electricity to reduce nitrogen to ammonia is a very attractive route. But still starting from how to say maybe 20 10 years ago, there is a big wave coming in doing this nitrogen reduction to ammonia. But the more published papers we see, but there comes out a big problem is the let's say it's like called the false positive signals coming from this result. That concerns a lot, not only my own research, but a lot of my friends inside the field, we have the concerns about how to repeat others results. It's because the current density nowadays we can do under the room temperature to reduce nitrogen is very, very small. It's less than maybe 0.1 milliamp. There is some report is 1 milliamp or even more. But it is really difficult for for people to repeat. This is also another consideration as Marcel has already mentioned the harbor Bosch, maybe, you know, several orders of magnitudes higher energy efficiency than using the electricity to reduce nitrogen to ammonia. Is that possible or it doesn't make sense for us to sacrifice some of the energy efficiencies to convert nitrogen to reduce nitrogen to ammonia or we improve the water splitting efficiency to generate the hydrogen we need and go through the harbor Bosch process to get the ammonia we need. That needs to be debated actually if at least at this current stage. But it's still open discussions like in the future we probably will get a very good catalyst to to add room temperature to reduce nitrogen to ammonia. That's that's also very possible.

annotations.expand on existing idea: HW expands on the previous discussion of hydrogen storage by focusing on the challenges and considerations of nitrogen reduction to ammonia as an alternative approach.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: HW supports their argument by mentioning the issue of false positive signals in nitrogen reduction research and the difficulty of replicating results due to low current density.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: HW points out the limitations and challenges associated with nitrogen reduction to ammonia, such as low current density and difficulty in replicating results, suggesting potential areas for improvement.
annotations.ask clarifying question: HW questions whether it's worthwhile to sacrifice energy efficiency for nitrogen reduction to ammonia or if improving water splitting efficiency and using the Haber-Bosch process is a better approach.

utterance: XS: I just like to add from a different perspective because I don't work on reactions, but more separations, is that there's a lot of interest I've seen from doing the reaction for nitrogen conversion from nitrates. And I think from a separation perspective, there is a advantage there is because you can recover waste nitrate of concentrated electrochemically and they use it for upcycling. So there's a lot of interesting electrochemical challenges in the nitrogen product and precursor separation that maybe when integrated with the reactions might make the overall system more efficient just because you can have one happening at the cathode, the other at the anode. So you have full integration. But I don't know how that fits into the whole energetics. I think from an electrochemical separation perspective, there's all sorts of sustainability and chemical consumption advantages.

annotations.present new idea: XS introduces the idea of using electrochemical separations for nitrogen conversion from nitrates, which has not been previously discussed.
annotations.expand on existing idea: XS builds upon the prior discussion of nitrogen conversion by suggesting an alternative approach focused on nitrate recovery and upcycling using electrochemical separations.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: XS mentions the observed interest in nitrogen conversion from nitrates as evidence for the potential of this approach.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: XS clarifies their focus on separations rather than reactions, setting the context for their subsequent contribution about nitrate conversion.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: XS implicitly suggests that current nitrogen conversion methods could be improved by integrating electrochemical separations for increased efficiency.

utterance: DK: One thing that's worth thinking about is trying to zoom out a little bit and think about, you know, what's the role of nitrogen in negative emissions? And the role is to sustain enhanced biological production that will draw down extra carbon dioxide. So I think there, you know, there's really good reason to question is that the best route to go, you know, how much carbon dioxide, how much additional carbon dioxide can you capture? What are the co-benefits of doing so? What are the disbenefits, like the extra consumption of say fresh water and nutrients on land? And then also, what's the degree of permanence? Like, you know, I live in California, a lot of our natural carbon a lot of our natural climate solutions just went up in flames in the last few months. And so when we're thinking about this role of nitrogen, um it's probably worth zooming out and thinking about, you know, what's the end fate of that nitrogen?

annotations.present new idea: David proposes to zoom out and consider the role of nitrogen in negative emissions and its broader implications, shifting the focus from specific methods to a systems-level perspective.
annotations.expand on existing idea: David builds upon the previous discussion about nitrogen's role in ammonia production by broadening the scope to encompass negative emissions and carbon capture.
annotations.ask clarifying question: David poses a series of questions about the effectiveness, benefits, drawbacks, and permanence of using nitrogen for negative emissions, prompting further discussion and analysis.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: David supports his argument by citing the example of wildfires in California, highlighting the impermanence of some natural climate solutions and the need to consider long-term effects.

utterance: MS: I would like to add to this. I think another role that actually ammonia can place as an energy carrier. I think it's it's a fairly elegant energy carrier. We can store it. Okay. Ammonia is a bit toxic. That's kind of the problem. On the other end, um we can actually liquefy it at reasonable temperatures, reasonable pressures. So it is a fairly good energy carrier. We can essentially attach hydrogen atoms to nitrogen, shuffle them around and and use them like Lindsay said. I think that's just something that we might also want to kind of keep in in view. It could be a very green, sustainable and thus reduce the carbon generation at least. It's not a carbon negative, so that's it's not a negative emission. It's a neutral emission technology.

annotations.expand on existing idea: MS expands on the prior discussion of nitrogen's role in negative emissions by focusing on ammonia's potential as an energy carrier.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: MS supports the idea of ammonia as an energy carrier by stating its properties, such as being liquefiable at reasonable temperatures and pressures, and its ability to store hydrogen.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: MS explains the concept of ammonia as an energy carrier by describing how hydrogen atoms can be attached to nitrogen and used.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: MS acknowledges the toxicity of ammonia as a drawback to its use as an energy carrier.

utterance: YL: I want to mention something about the fundamental side of the nitrogen reduction. So as mentioned, there are many experiments about nitrogen reduction to ammonium, which cannot be reproduced by other groups. And that's actually challenging for any needs for computational chemist like me because I try to for example, if I say a paper published for example in nature or science reporting very high performance for the catalytic and to reduction to ammonium. Then I would like to follow up with this experiment trying to understand why this catalyst is so good. What's what is the fundamental mechanism underlying this catalyst? But it turns out after sometime, this paper, I mean, cannot be reproduced. Some people are saying their experiments are not done carefully. So, so if I want to follow those papers, then I would, you know, waste some time trying to study something which is actually not experimentally verified. So I think, uh, yeah, it's very important to get clean experiments, reproducible experiments as a basis for computational studies.

annotations.propose decision: YL proposes that clean, reproducible experiments are crucial for computational studies in nitrogen reduction.

utterance: MS: I just have I have a kind of almost a kind of fundamental concern. So I first of all, I don't want to discredit research on nitrogen reduction because I think from a scientific perspective, it's fascinating. This nitrogen dinitrogen bond is fascinating. But when you then look at an engineering perspective, when we think about what we need to do to do an electrochemical transformation of nitrogen. Now we just think at scale, right? We need to bring in dinitrogen and we need to bring in protons and we need to bring in current. So we need obviously a kind of triple phase boundary or or kind of a gas diffusion electrode kind of design. This will be very difficult, especially if we're bringing in the gaseous species, which is very weakly soluble. I think that's where people struggle. Whereas if we are generating hydrogen in an electrolyzer, we have no transport problem. We just can bring water to the reaction side with very high transport rates, generate hydrogen, get the gas, and then convert it together with the second gas nitrogen in a in a in a Harbor Bosch process. So I just think when we look at this from this engineering perspective, right? This need for a triple phase boundary compared to the ease of generating hydrogen electrochemically, we may kind of find ourselves in this situation where when we want to do it at scale, we might we may find it hard to compete with the coupled Harbor Bosch and and electrolyzer design. I don't know what you guys think.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Marcel supports his argument against nitrogen reduction by highlighting the engineering challenges of scaling the process, specifically the difficulty of managing a triple-phase boundary and the weak solubility of gaseous species.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: Marcel is critiquing the scalability of nitrogen reduction, suggesting that the inherent difficulties in the process make it less competitive than the Harbor-Bosch process.
annotations.present new idea: Marcel introduces the idea of considering the engineering challenges of nitrogen reduction at scale, specifically the triple-phase boundary requirement and the weak solubility of gaseous species.
annotations.ask clarifying question: After presenting his concerns about the scalability of nitrogen reduction, Marcel asks the group for their thoughts on his perspective.

utterance: AT: I might have missed a little bit of that, but so you're saying that because the electrochemical row requires the addition of the proton there, I mean, when I think about that compared to the traditional Harbor Bosch, you do need the net thermodynamic states are going to be the same. So the net driving forces are the same. So are you saying it's an engineering challenge to get them all co-located on the active site?

annotations.ask clarifying question: AT asks for clarification on MS's point about the difficulty of electrochemical transformation of nitrogen due to the need for a triple-phase boundary, by questioning if the challenge lies in the co-location of reactants on the active site.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: AT explains that the net thermodynamic states and driving forces are the same for both electrochemical and Harbor-Bosch processes.

utterance: MS: A transport.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: Marcel clarifies that his previous concern was about the transport limitations in electrochemical nitrogen reduction.

utterance: MS: very the triple phase boundary variant in a classical catalytic environment. We have very good transport between two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site and then turning over to ammonia.

annotations.provide_supporting_evidence: The speaker explains that in a classical catalytic environment, there is good transport between two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site and turning over to ammonia, supporting their argument about the engineering challenges of electrochemical nitrogen reduction.
annotations.explain_or_define_term_or_concept: The speaker is explaining the concept of a triple phase boundary in the context of catalytic nitrogen conversion to ammonia.

utterance: AT: I mean, it's been you could argue that that transport has been fine-tuned over, you know, decades at least for development there of the fluidized bed technology to get there. And I don't know, to me, to me, it sounds like it's not a scientific barrier. It's a technical question of how are we going to do it as opposed to saying, even if we do get it, it won't be efficient.

annotations.expand on existing idea: AT expands on MS's point about the difficulty of electrochemical nitrogen reduction by arguing that the challenge lies in the technical implementation of a triple-phase boundary, similar to how fluidized bed technology has been optimized for the Haber-Bosch process.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: AT constructively critiques the view that electrochemical nitrogen reduction is inherently inefficient by framing the challenge as a technical one rather than a scientific one.
annotations.express alternative decision: Instead of dismissing electrochemical nitrogen reduction as inherently inefficient, AT suggests reframing the problem as a technical challenge of implementing a triple-phase boundary.

utterance: HW: It's it's I agree with Marshall. It's a big problem, but I also agree with Andrew that it could be solved. Like we can take examples from, let's say, oxygen reduction fuel cell. They also need these type of triple phase boundaries, but they can deliver very high current density, which means that you can also deliver very high production rates per area of your electro, right? But the challenge here now is we don't have platinum as efficient in OOR as iron catalyst. We can we can have for NRR. That's I think will be the critical challenge here to deliver the scale that you mentioned to compete with Harbor Bosch.

utterance: OL: Sorry. I just I just want to add a bit of organic chemist perspective on the matter. I feel like, you know, we're asked to dream big, right? And the topic is beyond CO2 and, you know, come up with the craziest idea we can come up with. And, you know, on one hand, from a from a from a chemistry perspective, the nitrogen molecule doesn't have a dipole, so it's really hard to activate for you at a surface, at a molecule, you name it. But on the other hand, you know, I think that there are from from a synthetic perspective, there are a lot of other products that could be made from a nitrogen reduction process. And so, you know, if that is a way to, you know, frame the question not necessarily in terms of replacing Harbor Bosch, which we know that is difficult, but maybe adding a different kind of value to to to a process. And so something that comes to mind is capturing carbon dioxide, converting it to formaldehyde, then making ammonia electrocatalytically, and there are some systems that do this, and then just adding a cyanide source and making amino acids. You know, these are basic building blocks for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science. And, you know, these discussions today have really kind of catalyzed these ideas where, you know, maybe we just need to think a little bit bigger, right? And, you know, Harbor Bosch is extraordinarily difficult to make an argument against, but maybe there there are other ways to to frame the problem as an opportunity in a different context.

annotations.present new idea: The speaker suggests exploring nitrogen reduction for purposes beyond replacing the Harbor-Bosch process, such as producing amino acids, which has not been previously discussed.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Building on the discussion of nitrogen reduction's challenges, the speaker proposes focusing on alternative valuable products besides ammonia.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker explains the challenge of nitrogen activation from an organic chemistry perspective, highlighting the lack of a dipole in the nitrogen molecule.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: The speaker implicitly encourages broader participation by suggesting the group "dream big" and "think a little bigger" about nitrogen's potential uses.

utterance: AT: I've got a slightly different pathway to bring up, I guess. Anyone have any ideas on NOx or NOx chemistry or if that could be related? Somebody mentioned how the nitrogen nitrogen bond is very stable, hard to break, while the nitrogen oxygen bond is a little bit easier. And if we're talking about CO2, I mean technically beyond CO2. But can CO2 be an oxidant to oxidize dinitrogen to form NOx, which then we can process downstream through other means? I know there's a lot of technology in NOx production out there already. So, just a thought to put out there.

annotations.present new idea: Andrew proposes a new idea of using CO2 as an oxidant to oxidize dinitrogen to form NOx, which can be processed downstream, as an alternative pathway in the discussion of nitrogen reduction.
annotations.provide supporting evidence: Andrew supports his idea by mentioning the existing technology in NOx production and the relative ease of breaking the nitrogen-oxygen bond compared to the nitrogen-nitrogen bond.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Andrew asks the group for their ideas on NOx chemistry and its potential relevance to the discussion.
annotations.encourage particpatioin: Andrew encourages participation by asking the group if they have any ideas on the proposed pathway.

I find it fascinating from an engineering perspective because one of the one of the interesting things about biomass as an energy source or a feedstock for anything is that it's very distributed. If you manage start to think about BECCS as a power source as well as a way to produce negative emissions, you're now talking about very distributed CO2 or carbon storage. So that leads me to thinking about a future landscape that has either a massive amount of CO2 pipelines if we're going to sequester CO2 geologically or a massive reliance on biochar and the associated costs with shipping solids around for sequestration. And so I'm just I'm unsure which of those two is is lower hanging fruit and more likely to be attainable in the short term because both from a systems engineering and logistics perspective seem complex to me. But if you look at climate models, there's always a massive amount of BECCS that's suggested as a solution for our negative emissions challenge. And in principle, the two parts are there, bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration, but putting them all together into a system seems really challenging to me.

annotations.present new idea: Chris introduces the concept of BECCS and its potential role in negative emissions, which had not been previously discussed.
annotations.explain or define term or concept: Chris explains that BECCS stands for bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Chris elaborates on the challenges of BECCS implementation, focusing on the distributed nature of biomass and the resulting complexities in CO2 or carbon storage.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Chris implicitly asks for the group's perspective on the feasibility and practicality of large-scale BECCS deployment, considering the challenges of CO2 pipelines and biochar transportation.

utterance: PM: I can jump in with a thought that I've discussed with one of my colleagues, Jeff Coates, who's a big CO2 to polymers researcher, about trying to do it's something we we're not we're not doing anything with this. It's too chemist talking, but about doing BECCS, but where, instead of sequestration, you you then feed the CO2 you capture into a CO2 polymerization site, and you essentially attach a biomass to CO2 unit onto your CO2 polymer facility, and you can use the energy perhaps to so you can make this little self-sustained essentially factory. I don't know if the economics of that could ever become reasonable, but that's something we've thought about as a way to avoid the like you said, this landscape of CO2 piping seems I don't know. It always seems kind of unreasonable to me that we're going to have all these pipes running all over just moving CO2 underground, but I don't know what your thoughts are about you know more about this than I do.

annotations.present new idea: Phil Nolner introduces a novel idea of combining BECCS with CO2 polymerization to create a self-sustaining factory, thus offering an alternative to CO2 sequestration and piping.
annotations.expand on existing idea: Phil expands on the existing discussion of CO2 sequestration and BECCS by suggesting an alternative approach that integrates CO2 polymerization.
annotations.offer constructive criticism: Phil constructively criticizes the idea of widespread CO2 piping by pointing out its logistical challenges and proposing a localized solution.
annotations.ask clarifying question: Phil asks for the group's thoughts on his idea, acknowledging that others may have more expertise on the topic.

utterance: CJ: I think it's a cool idea. Say hi to Jeff for me.

annotations.acknowledge contribution: Chris acknowledges Phil's idea of attaching a biomass to CO2 unit onto a CO2 polymer facility as "cool".
annotations.express enthusiasm: Chris expresses enthusiasm for Phil's idea by calling it "cool".

utterance: PM: Okay.

utterance: CJ: Yeah, if you do sort of a geographic analysis of the places where you can grow enough biomass with the places where you can also do sequestration, so you don't need to have all these pipelines, it gives you a you know, an array of areas, and there are quite a few where you could successfully do BECCS. So I do think BECCS has got a real positive potential in a bright future, but as a non-not a systems engineer, it does it does seem from a systems perspective complex to me.
